author: mklement0
body:
Observed in both Terminal.app and iTerm2.

Once you invoke PowerShell in a given Bash session, using the arrow keys in a subsequent invocation of the Perl6 REPL stops working, which prevents navigation inside a line and recall of commands from the history.

Even just invoking PowerShell with `-command`, without entering an interactive session, produces the symptom.

With PowerShell defined as the default shell, using the arrow keys in the Perl6 REPL is unavailable altogether.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

On macOS: 

* First, install Perl6 with `brew install perl6`.
* Run `perl6` to enter the Perl6 REPL and submit a command such as `'hi'` - verify that it can be recalled by pressing the up-arrow.
* Exit the REPL with `exit`
* Run a PowerShell command such as `pwsh -noprofile -command get-date`
* Enter the Perl6 REPL again with `perl6`
* Try to recall the previous command by pressing the up-arrow.

Expected behavior
-----------------

The most recently submitted command should be recalled from the command history.

Actual behavior
---------------

Nothing happens.

None of the arrow keys are working.

Environment data
----------------


```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.1.0 on macOS 10.13.6
```

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: @mklement0 Why is this not a Perl 6 bug?  It sounds like it's failing to properly (re)initialize the tty on startup.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@BrucePay: 

Since it doesn't happen with any of the major POSIX-like shells (`bash`, `dash`, `ksh`, `zsh`), I thought I'd start with PowerShell.

The fact that even a _noninteractive_, `-Command`-only invocation of PowerShell breaks subsequent command-line editing in Perl6 is especially curious.

Note that the editing isn't fully broken, since you can still type and submit commands; however, the arrow keys stop working (I've updated the initial post to clarify that).

comments.author: BrucePay
mklement0
comments.body: Good point, @BrucePay, but before I create an issue in the Perl6 repo: do you have any pointers as to what (a) PowerShell may be doing differently than other shells, and (b) what, specifically, Perl6 may be neglecting to do to cause this behavior?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body: I've created an issue in the Linenoise repo, which, from what I gather, provides Perl6's command-line editing - see  ~https://github.com/hoelzro/p6-linenoise/issues/27~ https://github.com/antirez/linenoise/issues/165

title: PowerShell breaks Perl6's (Rakudo's) command-line editing on macOS
